intro: Tapinanthus kayseri, commonly known as the Turkish dodder, is a parasitic plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies entirely on its host for nutrients. It belongs to the Orobanchaceae family and is characterized by its yellow-orange, thread-like stems that wrap around its host plants. The plant produces small, white or yellow flowers and has a unique reproductive strategy involving the production of seeds in specialized structures called pseudovaginas. It is native to the Mediterranean region and thrives in dry, arid environments. Due to its parasitic nature, it can cause significant damage to agricultural crops if left unchecked.
